items.title: Man charged over pipe bombs found in Canberra
items.description: The 41-year-old Belconnen man is charged in relation to the 15 pipe bombs found along the shore of Canberra's Lake Ginninderra this week.

items.title: Live: De Minaur gets lucky break as Australian Open gets underway
items.description: Luckless Italian star Matteo Berrettini withdraws from his first-round Australian Open clash with Alex de Minaur, as day one of the first tennis grand slam of 2026 kicks off with Carlos Alcaraz and Aryna Sabalenka the main attractions. Follow live.

items.title: 'Extremely wild weather': NSW coast battles heavy rainfall, flash flooding
items.description: The State Emergency Service responds to more than 1,400 incidents and 20 flood rescues, most of which involve people driving through floodwaters.

items.title: Trump asks countries to pay $1 billion for permanent peace board seats

featured_image.name: Trump asks Egypt, Turkey leaders to join Gaza Board of Peace

items.description:
The Trump administration is asking countries that want a permanent spot on President Donald Trump's new Board of Peace to contribute at least $1 billion, according to a draft charter of the body sent to world leaders this weekend.[1][2]

The provision, outlined in the charter distributed alongside invitation letters on Friday, effectively creates a two-tier membership structure. Countries that contribute $1 billion or more in cash funds to the Board of Peace would be exempt from the standard three-year membership term, securing them a permanent seat on the panel.[2]

items.title: Thousands protest Trump's Greenland push in Denmark, Arctic

featured_image.name: Protesters in Denmark support Greenland after Trump's takeover threat

items.description: Thousands of demonstrators took to the streets across Denmark and Greenland on Saturday, January 17, 2026, in a forceful rejection of President Donald Trump's escalating campaign to acquire the Arctic territory. The protests came hours after Trump announced sweeping tariffs on eight European nations opposing his push, deepening an unprecedented diplomatic rift between NATO allies.

items.title: None in family history, yet 'cancer still found us in the worst way'
items.description: Abbey was "joy on two legs" and now she's gone, another lost to brain cancer. Somehow her family must carry on as the fight for more funding to bring this horror disease to an end continues.

items.title: Macron slams Trump's Greenland tariff threats, vows united EU response

featured_image.name: Macron says Trump tariff threat over Greenland unacceptable

items.description:
French President Emmanuel Macron responded forcefully on Saturday to U.S. President Donald Trump's announcement of sweeping tariffs on eight European countries, declaring that "no intimidation or threat will influence us" and promising a united European response to what he called an unacceptable escalation.

The sharp rebuke came hours after Trump announced on Truth Social that Denmark, Norway, Sweden, France, Germany, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, and Finland would face a 10 percent tariff on all goods exported to the United States starting February 1, rising to 25 percent on June 1. The levies would remain in place "until such time as a Deal is reached for the Complete and Total purchase of Greenland," Trump said.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: Iran's Khamenei admits thousands killed in protests blaming US

featured_image.name: Khamenei calls Trump a 'criminal,' blames him for protest ...

items.description:
Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei on Saturday accused U.S. President Donald Trump of being a "criminal" responsible for casualties, destruction, and spreading falsehoods against the Iranian people, as the country emerges from its deadliest unrest in decades with thousands reported killed in a brutal crackdown.

"We consider the U.S. president a criminal for the casualties, damages, and the slander he inflicted on the Iranian nation," Khamenei said during a speech marking Eid al-Mab'ath, the anniversary of the Prophet Muhammad's mission, according to Iranian media. He described the protests as an "American sedition" designed to "devour Iran."[1][2]

items.title: The CIA orchestrated an Iranian coup seven decades ago. It still haunts the US
items.description: Protesters are urging US President Donald Trump to help dismantle Iran's theocracy. If he answers the call, it won't be the first time the US has toppled an Iranian government.

items.title: Trump held secret talks with Venezuela's Cabello before Maduro capture

featured_image.name: Delcy Rodriguez Addresses The Media Regarding The Release Of Prisoners In Venezuela

items.description:
The Trump administration held months of quiet discussions with Venezuela's interior minister Diosdado Cabello before the January 3 military operation that captured President Nicolás Maduro, and communications have continued since, according to multiple sources familiar with the matter in an exclusive Reuters report published Friday.[1][2]

U.S. officials warned Cabello, 62, against deploying security services or militant ruling-party supporters to target Venezuela's opposition, four sources told Reuters. The talks also addressed U.S. sanctions imposed on him and his federal drug-trafficking indictment. Despite being named in the same indictment that justified Maduro's arrest—with a $25 million bounty on his head—Cabello was not apprehended during the operation.[3][4]

items.title: NASA rolls Artemis II rocket to launch pad ahead of moon mission

featured_image.name: Artemis II Moon Mission: NASA Begins Rolling Giant Rocket to ...

items.description:
Canadian astronaut Jeremy Hansen stood at NASA's Kennedy Space Center in Florida on Saturday morning, watching as the rocket that will carry him around the moon began its slow journey to the launch pad. Hansen, a 49-year-old from London, Ontario, is set to become the first non-American to travel beyond low Earth orbit when Artemis II lifts off as early as next month.

The four-mile rollout of NASA's Space Launch System rocket and Orion spacecraft began at 7:04 a.m. EST on January 17, with the 11-million-pound stack creeping toward Launch Complex 39B at about one mile per hour. The journey to the launch pad is expected to take up to 12 hours.[1][2]

items.title: Trump announces 10 percent tariffs on Denmark and allies over Greenland

featured_image.name: Trump threatens tariffs for nations that don't support his aim to acquire Greenland

items.description:
President Donald Trump escalated his campaign to acquire Greenland on Saturday by announcing a 10 percent tariff on eight European countries that have rallied behind Denmark in opposing U.S. control of the Arctic territory.

In a post on Truth Social, Trump said the tariffs would take effect on February 1 and apply to Denmark, Norway, Sweden, France, Germany, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, and Finland. According to Investing.com, the tariffs would increase to 25 percent on June 1 and remain in place until "a deal is reached for the United States to purchase Greenland".[1][2][3]

items.title: BHP popular with investors as CBA loses its shine in market
items.description: The year is barely underway but already there's a power struggle between our biggest corporations as they fight it out for line honours.

items.title: Trump vows tariffs on eight European countries over Greenland stand-off
items.description: Donald Trump announces the escalating tariffs for Denmark, Norway, Sweden, France, Germany, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands and Finland as a row over Greenland continues.

items.title: Liberal election autopsy delayed after Dutton suggests report defamatory
items.description: The report, co-authored by Liberal grandees Pru Goward and Nick Minchin, has now been sent to a legal team to ensure it is watertight while the party decides what step to take next.

items.title: US House committee accuses South Africa of threatening national security

featured_image.name: US Ratchets Up Criticism of South Africa After BRICS War ...

items.description:
The United States has intensified its condemnation of South Africa following the "Will for Peace 2026" naval exercises that concluded on Friday off Cape Town's coast, with the House Committee on Foreign Affairs accusing Pretoria of undermining American national security. The criticism comes one day after the US Embassy in South Africa publicly lambasted the country for allowing Iran to participate in the drills alongside Chinese and Russian vessels.[1][2]

The week-long exercises, which ran from January 9 to 16, brought together naval forces from Iran, China, Russia, South Africa, and the United Arab Emirates, along with observers from Brazil, Ethiopia, Indonesia, and Egypt. The drills are described by South African officials as part of the BRICS Plus framework aimed at enhancing maritime security.[3][4][5]

items.title: Putin's 'worst-case scenario' could be realised in Iran regime change
items.description: Tehran is the epicentre of the nightly protests shaking Iran's regime, but the reverberations are being felt loud and clear in Moscow, too.

items.title: On the world's largest hospital ship volunteers give people a chance at a better life
items.description: On the largest civilian hospital ship in the world, Australian volunteers provide life-changing healthcare that is transforming lives.

items.title: China breaks ground on world's first hybrid nuclear plant for petrochemicals

featured_image.name: China starts construction of innovative nuclear project ...

items.description:
China has begun construction of the world's first large-scale nuclear power plant designed to directly supply industrial steam to the petrochemical sector, marking a new approach to decarbonizing heavy industry.

On Friday, workers poured the first concrete for the nuclear island of Unit 1 at the Xuwei Nuclear Heating and Power Plant in Lianyungang, Jiangsu Province, according to China National Nuclear Corporation (CNNC), the state-owned developer. The project is the first nuclear power unit to break ground in the opening year of China's 15th Five-Year Plan, which runs from 2026 to 2030.[1][2][3]

items.title: Malaysia says Grok ban won't lift until X proves misuse 'will no longer occur'

featured_image.name: Malaysia blocks Grok amid uproar over nonconsensual sexualised ...

items.description:
Malaysia and Indonesia have become the first countries in the world to block access to Elon Musk's AI chatbot Grok after regulators determined the tool was being used to generate sexually explicit and nonconsensual deepfake images, including content depicting women and minors.

Indonesia's Ministry of Communication and Digital Affairs ordered restrictions on January 10, with Malaysia's Communications and Multimedia Commission following on January 11. The bans came after officials in both countries concluded that safeguards implemented by xAI, the company behind Grok, had failed to stop the spread of obscene content on X, the social media platform formerly known as Twitter.[1][2][3][4][5]

items.title: President Trump Announces U.S. Military Airstrike in Venezuela
items.description: President Trump states the U.S. military conducted its first known airstrike inside Venezuela targeting a dock where drugs were allegedly loaded onto boats[1][2][4].
